page.title: 10Parish Church of Southam
page.content: St. James Church spire is often the first thing people see as they approach Southam. The church was built in the 14th century, replacing another church built in 1220. In pre- Reformation days it was a Catholic church. The last mass to be said there was in about 1547. Below the spire (attributed to the perpendicular style) is the belfry which houses 8 bells used for worship and celebration. The people of Southam were in disgrace when Charles 1st visited the town as the church bells weren't rung to celebrate his arrival. The parish was fined and the church doors were locked as a punishment. Inside the church is an old chest which kept the Parish records. There also remains a cannon ball from the battle of Southam. The church is used for concerts, recitals and festivals.
